awd_abstract_narration:
Earlier research by the Principal Investigator introduced the concept of a "dignity taking," linking the unconsented taking of property rights with the deprivation of dignity.  Seeking to further understand the relationship between property and dignity, this research project extends the earlier analysis to the case of squatting.  Among other things, the research will help illuminate why some populations choose to squat instead of pursing alternative accommodations, and how these risky and illegal actions may enhance or degrade their dignity.

The field-based research will focus on a case study of squatters in Detroit.  Methods include semi-structured interviews, focus group interviews, and photo elicitation interviews.  The study will 1) expand research on property rights, property takings, and squatting; 2) contribute to and extend scholarly work on legal consciousness; and 3) deepen scholarship on how and why people navigate illegality.

por.por_cntn:
The racially discriminatory administration of property taxes in urban centers adversely affects communities of color. But, given the complexity of property tax calculations, most affected communities are unaware of the injustice. The project highlighted this nsidious yet invisible form of institutional racism.

From 2011 to 2015, the Wayne County treasurer foreclosed upon about 1 in 4 Detroit properties for nonpayment of property taxes. The Great Depression was the last time in American history that a city has experienced this record numbers of property tax foreclosures. According to the Michigan Constitution, no property should be assessed at more than 50% of its market value. But, my research with Tim Hodge shows that between 2009-2015, the City of Detroit assessed 55% to 85% of its properties in violation of the Michigan constitution. Since property taxes were based on these illegally inflated numbers, it is no surprise that residents simply couldn’t pay. As a result, over 100,000 working families have lost their homes through tax foreclosure and many Detroit neighborhoods have been devastated.

In another study that I conducted with Christopher Berry, we find that—controlling for purchase price, location, and time-of-sale—10 percent of Detroit homes would not have gone through tax foreclosure but for the illegally inflated tax assessments. The empirical evidence resolutely suggests that Detroit’s unrivaled property tax foreclosure rates are illegitimate.

The racial aspects of illegal property tax assessments are profound. In a recent study, I find that unconstitutional tax assessments and property tax foreclosures occur at a significantly higher rate in Wayne County’s predominately African-American cities (like Detroit, Inkster, and Highland Park) than in its predominately white ones. Most concerning, Detroit is not the only city engaging in racially discriminatory property tax administration. A recent Pulitzer Prize-nominated Chicago Tribune series found that homes in minority neighborhoods on the south and west sides of Chicago were paying effective tax rates twice as high as those in wealthier, predominately white neighborhoods on the north side. Recent research by Christopher Berry shows that racialized property tax administration is a national problem. Nonetheless, most affected communities and their advocates are unaware that systemic racism lurks in the complex calculations of their property tax bills.

To highlight these problems, I published four scholarly articles and I am working on a book manuscript. My work was widely diseminated through prominent media outlets such as the New York Times, Washington Post, HBO’s Vice News, NPR’s Democracy Now!, the Tavis Smiley Show, Michigan Public Radio’s Stateside, Detroit News, and Detroit Free Press. Through my research, I have taken the problem of racially discriminatory property tax administration from the shadows of popular and academic discourse to its center stage.

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2020
Modified by: Bernadette Atuahene
